results.title: Barbarosa
results.creator_credit: Fred Schepisi and William D. Wittliff
results.brief_description: Karl Westover, an inexperienced farm boy, runs away after unintentionally killing a neighbor, whose family pursues him for vengeance. He meets Barbarosa, a gunman of near-mythical proportions, who is himself in danger from his father-in-law Don Braulio, a wealthy Mexican rancher.

constellations_other.name: Fred Schepisi
constellations_other.description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

results.description: Karl Westover, an inexperienced farm boy, runs away after unintentionally killing a neighbor, whose family pursues him for vengeance. He meets Barbarosa, a gunman of near-mythical proportions, who is himself in danger from his father-in-law Don Braulio, a wealthy Mexican rancher. Don Braulio wants Barbarosa dead for marrying his daughter against the father’s will. Barbarosa reluctantly takes the clumsy Karl on as a partner, as both of them look to survive the forces lining up against them.
description_for_label: Karl Westover, an inexperienced farm boy, runs away after unintentionally killing a neighbor, whose family pursues him for vengeance. He meets Barbarosa, a gunman of near-mythical proportions, who is himself in danger from his father-in-law Don Braulio, a wealthy Mexican rancher. Don Braulio wants Barbarosa dead for marrying his daughter against the father’s will. Barbarosa reluctantly takes the clumsy Karl on as a partner, as both of them look to survive the forces lining up against them.

constellations_other.name: Go Bang
constellations_other.description: Australian dance act PNAU are renowned for groundbreaking visuals in their music videos, including for their 2017 single 'Go Bang' which featured Kira Divine.

results.title: Play safe
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Dennis Hill Productions, John Morris, Education Dept of S A and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: The fun of swimming and participating in water sports can be spoiled unless basic safety rules and techniques are known, practised and used. This comprehensive water safety film covers all aspects from drown-proofing to the use of life-jackets, to a full illustration of the Royal Life Saving Award technique of safe non-contact rescue. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Keith Gow, Dennis Hill Productions, John Morris, Education Dept of S A and South Australian Film Corporation

results.title: Horror Movie – Skyhooks
results.brief_description: The colourful and quirky music video for Skyhooks’ song ‘Horror Movie’ (1974) helped mark Australian television’s transition from black and white to colour as it was first played on a special, midnight episode of Countdown (1974–87).

constellations_primary.name: Horror movie right there on my TV
constellations_primary.description: The colourful and quirky music video for Skyhooks’ song 'Horror Movie' helped propel them to number one, making it their biggest hit.

constellations_other.name: The secret life of suburbia and music videos
constellations_other.description: Australia's famous streets and suburbs have defined music videos, TV shows and miniseries, providing a unique backdrop to Australian stories and music.

results.description: The colourful and quirky music video for Skyhooks’ song Horror Movie (1974) helped mark Australian television’s transition from black and white to colour as it was first played on a special, midnight episode of Countdown (1974–87). Despite being a political commentary on the state of current affairs at the time, the song became an unintentional Halloween classic after it was included on a compilation album from actress Cassandra Petersen’s character Elvira in 1988.
description_for_label: The colourful and quirky music video for Skyhooks’ song Horror Movie (1974) helped mark Australian television’s transition from black and white to colour as it was first played on a special, midnight episode of Countdown (1974–87). Despite being a political commentary on the state of current affairs at the time, the song became an unintentional Halloween classic after it was included on a compilation album from actress Cassandra Petersen’s character Elvira in 1988.

results.title: Song to Sing – Archie Roach
results.brief_description: Melbourne band The Bombay Royale make “vintage Bollywood-inspired surf, spy, disco and funk” and their video for Wild Stallion Mountain (2015) clearly reflects that, playing like a mash-up of Bollywood, 60s psychedelia, kitsch, exploitation cinema and classic Hollywood Westerns.
results.description: Strongly influenced by gospel in sound and style, ‘Song to Sing’ comes on the heels of Indigenous Australian musician Archie Roach suffering immense personal loss following the death of his partner two years earlier and his own health problems. The black and white video matches the uplifting rhythm of the track and features cameos from several prominent Australians including Roach himself, Jack Charles, Lou Bennett and Emma Donovan.
description_for_label: Strongly influenced by gospel in sound and style, ‘Song to Sing’ comes on the heels of Indigenous Australian musician Archie Roach suffering immense personal loss following the death of his partner two years earlier and his own health problems. The black and white video matches the uplifting rhythm of the track and features cameos from several prominent Australians including Roach himself, Jack Charles, Lou Bennett and Emma Donovan.

results.title: Party – Christine Anu
results.brief_description: The third single off her debut album, Party (1995) remains Christine Anu’s biggest hit to date. On the surface, the clip seems consistent with other upbeat, pop videos of the 90s with overlaid images and montages to match the mood of the song. However, Anu cleverly incorporated her Torres Strait Islander heritage into the video with choreography that was a mix of traditional dances and modern styles, not to mention a diverse cast of extras and backup dancers.

results.title: Pool Party – Julia Jacklin
results.brief_description: Intoxicated detachment is the mood most easily evoked in singer/songwriter Julia Jacklin’s music video for ‘Pool Party’ (2016). Featuring her drummer Tom Stephens as the co-star, it recalls a distinct 70s aesthetic with an Australian twist as it was filmed in Jacklin’s hometown, the Blue Mountains.
results.description: Intoxicated detachment is the mood most easily evoked in singer/songwriter Julia Jacklin’s music video for Pool Party (2016). Featuring her drummer Tom Stephens as the co-star, it calls to a distinct 70s aesthetic with an Australian twist as it was filmed in Jacklin’s birthplace, the Blue Mountains. As hypnotic as it is uncomfortable, it follows two characters as they struggle to meet in the middle visually, physically, and lyrically.
description_for_label: Intoxicated detachment is the mood most easily evoked in singer/songwriter Julia Jacklin’s music video for Pool Party (2016). Featuring her drummer Tom Stephens as the co-star, it calls to a distinct 70s aesthetic with an Australian twist as it was filmed in Jacklin’s birthplace, the Blue Mountains. As hypnotic as it is uncomfortable, it follows two characters as they struggle to meet in the middle visually, physically, and lyrically.

results.title: Everything You Wanted – Clubfeet
results.brief_description: Clubfeet’s music video for Everything You Wanted (2013) seems straightforward on first watch but was a complicated and technically ambitious feat to execute. Director Josh Thomas used a Red Epic at 5k resolution to film the clip in one take at 50 frames a second.
results.description: Clubfeet’s music video for Everything You Wanted (2013) seems straightforward on first watch, but was actually a complicated and technically ambitious feat to execute. Director Josh Thomas used a Red Epic at 5k resolution to film the clip in one take at 50 frames a second, with the masking out of each still pose achieved in post. The technique was so effective, it was controversially used in One Direction’s video You & I (2014), raising questions of inspiration, reinvention and duplication.
description_for_label: Clubfeet’s music video for Everything You Wanted (2013) seems straightforward on first watch, but was actually a complicated and technically ambitious feat to execute. Director Josh Thomas used a Red Epic at 5k resolution to film the clip in one take at 50 frames a second, with the masking out of each still pose achieved in post. The technique was so effective, it was controversially used in One Direction’s video You & I (2014), raising questions of inspiration, reinvention and duplication.

results.title: Did It Again – Kylie Minogue
results.credit_line: ℗ 1994 Mushroom Records Pty. Ltd. (Seaman / Minogue / Anderson)
results.brief_description: For years, Kylie Minogue had been trying to break out of the boxes the press was determined to put her in: the pop star, bad girl, icon. In Did It Again, she confronted and combated each version of herself in a scenario inspired by The Usual Suspects (1995).

constellations_primary.name: Kylie to Lucy
constellations_primary.description: 'Did It Again' started the conversation about Kylie Minogue being more than just a pop star, it started to cement her status as one of the most important audio and visual artists of her time, but the video had an unlikely inspiration.

results.description: For years, Kylie Minogue had been trying to break out of the boxes the press were determined to put her into: Kylie the pop star, Kylie the bad girl, Kyle the icon. In the music video for ‘Did It Again’, she got to confront and combat each version of herself in a scenario inspired by The Usual Suspects. One of her most enduring hits, the video also cemented her status as a boundary-pushing visual artist.
description_for_label: For years, Kylie Minogue had been trying to break out of the boxes the press were determined to put her into: Kylie the pop star, Kylie the bad girl, Kyle the icon. In the music video for ‘Did It Again’, she got to confront and combat each version of herself in a scenario inspired by The Usual Suspects. One of her most enduring hits, the video also cemented her status as a boundary-pushing visual artist.
results.credit_line_for_label: ℗ 1994 Mushroom Records Pty. Ltd. (Seaman / Minogue / Anderson)

results.title: Treaty – Yothu Yindi
results.credit_line: ℗ 1991 Yothu Yindi (Yunupingu / Kellaway / Williams / Yunupingu / Mu)
results.brief_description: Montage is commonly used in music videos, yet in Yothu Yindi’s ‘Treaty’ (1991) it helped communicate the musicians’ disdain for “all those talking politicians” as footage of then Prime Minister Bob Hawke at the presentation of the Barunga Statement intersected with the powerful lyrics.
results.description: Montage is a common tool used in many music videos, yet in the case of Yothu Yindi’s song Treaty (1991) it helped communicate the musicians disdain for “all those talking politicians” as footage of then Prime Minister Bob Hawke at the presentation of the Barunga Statement intersected with the powerful lyrics. The spliced images became a political statement, with director Stephen Johnson making sure the micro-documentary was put it in a form where audiences who didn’t watch the news would see it.
description_for_label: Montage is a common tool used in many music videos, yet in the case of Yothu Yindi’s song Treaty (1991) it helped communicate the musicians disdain for “all those talking politicians” as footage of then Prime Minister Bob Hawke at the presentation of the Barunga Statement intersected with the powerful lyrics. The spliced images became a political statement, with director Stephen Johnson making sure the micro-documentary was put it in a form where audiences who didn’t watch the news would see it.
results.credit_line_for_label: ℗ 1991 Yothu Yindi (Yunupingu / Kellaway / Williams / Yunupingu / Mu)
